item.title: Federation - how it works here?
item.description: After recent updates, I've made federation working properly. Now every change (new post, edited blog, edited post, deleted stuff) are pushed into your followers in ActivityPub protocol. How federation works in...
item.content:encoded:
After recent updates, I've made federation working properly. Now every change (new post, edited blog, edited post, deleted stuff) are pushed into your followers in ActivityPub protocol.

How federation works in openwrite?

Basically, from tools using Person activitypub object (like Mastodon) you can follow your blog and see/like posts in there. To view your blog in Mastodon, search for it, in searchbar type: blogname@openwrite.io, so looking for this blog, I will search for main@openwrite.io:

After accessing the profile, you'll see your description (set in dashboard under Custom ActivityPub profile description - marked in red), blog title as name and blog url as username:

If you don't see your previous posts, don't worry. Posts are not backpulled in mastodon, but after following the blog, you will see new posts in your feed. As for post types, if post is less than 200 characters long, it will be pushed as Note object. If longer, it will become an Article.

So, after following your blog, you will see your post in Mastodon feed:

And likes from Mastodon will transfer here :)

item.content:encoded:
Here you'll find information about migrating posts from another platforms. Accepted formats are CSV and XML(from wordpress).

Posts export from Wordpress

  1. To export posts from Wordpress, login into your blog, go to admin page.

  2. Go to Tools -> Export, select posts you want to export, click on Download Export File:

Posts export from Write Freely

  1. To export posts from Write Freely, login into the instance, then go to: export page.

  2. Click on csv link in the row with Posts:

  3. Change headers in csv file to match this:

    title content date
    Post title Post content Post date

Posts export from Bear Blog

  1. To export posts from Bear Blog, login into the instance, select your blog and go to settings.

  2. Click on export all blog data:

  3. Change headers in csv file to match this:

    title content date
    Post title Post content Post date

item.description: Here you will find the basics of Markdown usage: Headings You can create headings by starting a line with one or more # symbols. Heading 1 Code: # Heading 1 Heading 2 Code: ## Heading 2 Heading...
item.content:encoded:
Here you will find the basics of Markdown usage:

Headings

You can create headings by starting a line with one or more # symbols.

Heading 1

Code: # Heading 1

Heading 2

Code: ## Heading 2

Heading 3

Code: ### Heading 3

Text Styles

Style your text to add emphasis.

This is bold text

Code: **This is bold text** or __This is bold text__

This is italic text

Code: *This is italic text* or _This is italic text_

This is strikethrough text

Code: ~~This is strikethrough text~~

This is a quote.

Code: > This is a quote.

Lists

Unordered List

Use asterisks *, pluses +, or hyphens - to create bullet points.

  • First item
  • Second item
    • Nested item

Code:

* First item
* Second item
  * Nested item

Ordered List

Use numbers followed by a period.

  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item

Code:

1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item

Links

Create a hyperlink by wrapping the link text in brackets [ ] and the URL in parentheses ( ).

Visit the official Markdown guide

Code: [Visit the official Markdown guide](https://www.markdownguide.org)

Images

To add an image, use an exclamation mark ! followed by alt text in brackets [ ] and the image URL in parentheses ( ).

Code: ![openwrite logo](https://openwrite.io/static/logo.png)

Image options

To edit the image dimensions, you can use = followed by width and height. * can be used for "auto".

To add caption to the image, you can use "caption" at the end.

Code: ![openwrite logo](https://openwrite.io/static/logo.png =400x* "This is resized image with caption")

Code

Inline Code

Wrap your code with single backticks `.

Use the create_engine() function to connect.

Code: Use the `create_engine()` function to connect.

Code Blocks

Wrap your code block with three backticks . You can also specify the language for syntax highlighting.

from sqlalchemy import create_engine

# Use the PyMySQL driver
engine = create_engine('mysql+pymysql://user:pass@host/db')

Code:

```python
from sqlalchemy import create_engine

# Use the PyMySQL driver
engine = create_engine('mysql+pymysql://user:pass@host/db')
```
